bibl.title: Letter from David L. Andrus to Philip Showalter Hench, March 2, 1938

div1.p: Dr. David Andrus gives his assessment of the medical condition and history of John Andrus, his father.

div1.head: Letter from David L. Andrus to Philip Showalter Hench, March 2, 1938
div1.opener:
DAVID L. ANDRUS, M. D.
805 COOPER STREET
CAMDEN, NEW JERSEY
March 2, 1938.
Dr. Philip S. Hench,
% Mayo Clinic,
Rochester, Minn.
Dear Doctor Hench:
div1.p:
The purpose of this letter is to outline my Father's past and
present condition, in which you have expressed interest.

At the outset may I assure you that there is nothing resembling
a controversy between Walter Reed Hospital and myself - merely
a difference of opinion - of which they are unaware.

About 1912 my Father began to develop severe costal pain, most
marked on the abdominal wall, but relieved only by application
of heat over the dorso-lumbar spine. Back pain and deformity
developed slowly and insidiously until ultimately, over a period
of six years, a rigid lordosis, most marked in the lower cervical
and upper dorsal region, developed.

A spinal brace with crutches, throwing the weight of the trunk
on the femeral trochanters, was prescribed and worn for years
with gradual progression of the arthritic pathology until, ulti-
mately, parasthesias and muscular weakness with spastic, Tabetic
type gait, became progressive; this would be relieved, temporar-
ily, by rest in bed. (Mild extension.)

Finally complete spastic paraplegia of all four extremities re-
sulted, accompanied by sphincteric involvement. Admission
to Walter Reed Hospital - Neuro-Psychiatric Section - followed.

Study confirmed findings prior to this by a Radiologist, Ortho-
poedist and Neurologist whom I had called in. No foci of
infection could be demonstrated. At no time was there loss
of pain and temperature-sense nor any findings making a diagno-
sis of syringo myelia tenable.

Gradual improvement followed complete rest and physiotherapy.
(Heat and massage to extremities.) It was decided that the
spinal damage was too far advanced to permit mechanical exten-
Dr. Hench.
Page 2.
sion or operative interference such as Albee Bone Graft.

Finally, good function of all four extremities was restored, if
kept recumbent, and discharge from Walter Reed Hospital followed.
Their final diagnosis being Syringo Myelia.

Since then very slow progression of parasthesia and recent shoul-
der-girdle, cervical and occipital pains have occurred.
All are aggravated by even fleeting departure from horizontal
position.

Tendency to attacks of Paroxysmal Tacchycardia have been con-
trolled by one grain of digitalis daily.

In closing may I say that all of the X-ray, neurological and
clinical evidence indicates, to me, that the condition is a
typical Spondylitis, of Von Bechterew type. (Classical nerve-
root pressure symptoms.)
Any advice or suggestions you may offer will be very welcome.
